ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class went through the history of French New Wave, from the directors to their films.
I learned a lot about various periods in French film history.
Historical knowledge about french cinema, ability to analyze and compare different aspects of cinema. Skills to read films.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not a lot of individual feedback for students not in media studies

Strengths: I thought the Professor and TAs worked well together and that the breakout sessions provided good opportunities for deeper discussions. Likewise, I thought the films that we watched were on the whole excellent. 

Weaknesses: Sometimes the structure of our virtual classes could be a bit chaotic.
Strengths are the lecture and discussion mixture.
One of the greatest strengths was how knowledgeable Prof. Andrew was about this topic and how interested he was to hear what we thought.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: For the most part, I felt that this course was well-geared towards a virtual environment. Having us sign up for the Criterion subscription helped ease any issues with accessing films.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Take this class if you are absolutely sure about learning more about French cinema. Professor Andrew is very passionate about the topic and could talk for hours about any French director or discuss any French film in detail.
If youre interested in the movies yes. Not all of them are really accessible. And I think the lectures are best if you already know a little about movie history.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student! Professor Andrew is a gem and you get to watch so many wonderful, thought-provoking films. Bonus points for the lovely discussion with other students.
Yes, if you are interested in film or in french.

Yes! You will learn so much in this class about film but also about social movements and changes in France in the twentieth century through watching films, and there's nothing more fun to do for homework than watch films!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The lectures also included "section" discussions for about 25 minutes of class time.
